revision.comment: Fixed typo, Sunday should be capitalized
revision.text:
{{About||the video game|Bubble and Squeak (video game)|the album|Bubble and Squeak (album)|the cartoon|Bubble and Squeek}} {{use British English|date=December 2019}} {{use mdy dates|date=December 2019}} {{refimprove|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox food | name = Bubble and squeak | image = Full English breakfast with bubble and squeak, sausage, bacon, grilled tomatoes, and eggs.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = A small portion of bubble and squeak (left), as part of an [[English breakfast]] | alternate_name = | country = [[United Kingdom]] | region = | creator = | course = | type = | served = | main_ingredient = [[Potato]]es, [[cabbage]], [[Brussels sprout]]s, [[vegetable]]s | variations = | calories = | other = | cookbook = Bubble and Squeak }} [[File:Bubble and squeak with poached egg.jpg|thumb|Bubble and squeak topped with poached egg]]
'''Bubble and squeak''' is a traditional [[United Kingdom|British]] [[breakfast]] dish made from potatoes and cabbage.
In modern times, it is a dish made with the shallow-fried Sunday [[leftovers|leftover]] vegetables from a [[roast dinner]]. The main ingredients are [[potato]] and [[cabbage]], but [[carrot]]s, [[pea]]s, [[Brussels sprout|sprout]]s, or any other leftover vegetables may be added. The chopped vegetables (and cold chopped meat, if used) are fried in a pan together with mashed potatoes or crushed roast potatoes until the mixture is well-cooked and brown on the sides. The dish is so named because the cabbage makes bubbling and squeaking sounds during the cooking process.<ref>{{citation |author=Pickett, Joseph P. |title=American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language |publisher=Houghton Mifflin |year=2000 |display-authors=etal}}.</ref> It is often served with cold meat from the [[Sunday roast]] and pickles or [[brown sauce]], or as an accompaniment to a [[full breakfast|full English breakfast]].
The meat was traditionally added to the bubble and squeak, although nowadays it is more commonly made without meat. The earliest-known recipe was in [[Maria Rundell|Mrs Rundell]]'s ''[[A New System of Domestic Cookery]]'' in 1806.<ref name="rundell">Rundell, Maria Eliza Ketelby (1808). Bubble and Squeak. In ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=30tOAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA42#v=onepage&q&f=false A new system of domestic cookery:Third edition]''. p. 42. Google Book Search. Retrieved on 6 January 2011.</ref>
The name ''bubble and squeak'' is used primarily in England (for Scotland and Ireland<ref> In Canada where the term may have originated, it usually refers strictly to a dish of the leftovers of a cottage roll dinner. [http://britishfood.about.com/od/scottishregionalrecipes/r/rumbledethumps.htm Scottish Recipes: Rumbledethumps Recipe<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> see the section [[#Similar dishes|Similar dishes]]), and it may also be understood in parts of some other Commonwealth countries and the United States.<ref name="usa">[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SaQtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=n50FAAAAIBAJ&dq=bubble&pg=4819%2C2454303 Hearty Luncheon and Supper Dishes] Reading Eagle, 17 July 1913.</ref><ref name="usa2">[https://www.forbes.com/2004/11/17/cx_cv_1117food.html Forbes Lifestyle, Wine and Food] Forbes, 17 November 2004.</ref>
Bubble and squeak has been a popular dish since the late 1800s, as it was an easy way of using leftovers. In more recent times, ready-made pre-prepared versions have become available on the market.
== Similar dishes == * [[Panackelty]], from [[North East England]] * [[Rumbledethumps]], [[stovies]] and [[clapshot]] from [[Scottish cuisine|Scotland]] * [[Colcannon]] and [[Champ (food)|champ]], from [[Irish cuisine|Ireland]] * [[Stoemp]] from [[Belgium]] * [[Calentao]], from [[Colombia]] * [[Biksemad]], from [[Denmark]] * [[Stemmelkort]], from [[Germany]] * [[Stamppot]], from the [[Dutch cuisine|Netherlands]] * [[Trinxat]], from the [[La Cerdanya]] region of [[Catalonia]], northeast [[Spain]] and [[Andorra]] * [[Pyttipanna|Pyttipanna, Pyttipanne and Pyttipannu]] (from the [[Swedish language|Swedish]] "pytt i panna"="small pieces in pan") from [[Sweden]], [[Norway]] and [[Finland]] * [[Hash (food)|Hash]], from the [[United States]] * [[Aloo tikki]], from [[India]] * [[Matev≈æ]], from [[Slovenian cuisine|Slovenia]] * Tortilla de verduras, from [[Chile]]{{cn|date=January 2019}} * Fry up (from Wales)
